summary: This document is a series of email exchanges between U.S. Department of Justice officials in August 2021 regarding the drafting and submission of an MLAT (Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty) request to the United Kingdom related to the Ghislaine Maxwell case (referenced as 'Maxwell 182-73090'). The discussion centers on obtaining travel records, specifically border crossing information for Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, with concerns raised that such a request might trigger scrutiny due to potential connections to Prince Andrew.

persons.name: John T. McNeil
persons.role: U.S. Department of Justice Attaché - London
persons.context: DOJ official based at the U.S. Embassy in London coordinating the submission of an MLAT request to the UK Central Authority (UKCA) for the Maxwell investigation. He advises on strategy and drafts the request.

persons.name: Lara
persons.context: A prosecutor or attorney from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) leading the effort to obtain UK travel records for the Maxwell case. She drafts the MLAT request and corresponds with McNeil.

persons.name: Taylor Cole
persons.context: DOJ attorney copied on the email chain, involved in the discussion about the MLAT request.

persons.name: Jennifer L. Schroeder-Fawcett
persons.role: Attaché, U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP)
persons.context: CBP Attaché in London who provides technical information about the availability and data fields of travel records (APIS/PNR) that might be held by CBP.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the investigation; the MLAT request seeks his border crossing/travel records from the UK.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the investigation and prosecution (case 'Maxwell 182-73090'); the MLAT request seeks her border crossing/travel records from the UK.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned by John McNeil as a potential complicating factor; he worries UK authorities might think the travel record request is aimed at investigating Prince Andrew, which could cause delays.

connections.description: Collaborating on drafting and submitting an MLAT request from the U.S. to the UK for the Ghislaine Maxwell investigation.
DOJ colleagues copied on official correspondence regarding the MLAT request.
McNeil consults Schroeder-Fawcett, the CBP Attaché, for information on the availability of historical travel records.
Both are subjects of the same investigation, and the MLAT request seeks travel records for both individuals.
Implied by McNeil's concern that a request for Maxwell/Epstein travel data might be perceived by UK authorities as an attempt to investigate Prince Andrew.

events.title: Drafting of MLAT Request to UK
events.description: Email exchanges between DOJ officials in the U.S. and London to finalize a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty request to the United Kingdom for travel/border crossing records of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: MLAT Request Signed and Ready
events.description: John McNeil receives a signed version of the MLAT request and indicates he will send it to the UK Central Authority (UKCA).

locations: London SW11 7US, United Kingdom (U.S. Embassy, 33 Nine Elms Lane)
keyFacts: DOJ officials were actively seeking UK travel and border crossing records for Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell via an MLAT request in August 2021.

A key concern raised was that requesting Epstein and Maxwell's border data might cause the UK authorities to 'pause and give this greater scrutiny' because they might think the U.S. was 'trying to get information about Prince Andrew.'

The document reveals interagency coordination between DOJ and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to locate historical travel records, with note that CBP destroys PNR (ticketing) data after 5 years but retains flight manifest data longer.
The correspondence is part of the investigation into Ghislaine Maxwell, referenced under case number 'Maxwell 182-73090'.
